file_summary: This configuration file is used to define database connection settings for a Spring Boot application. It explicitly sets the `database` type to `mysql`, indicating the application's preference or requirement to use MySQL. It configures the essential `spring.datasource` properties including the JDBC URL, username, and password. These values are designed to be flexible, allowing default fallbacks (e.g., `jdbc:mysql://localhost/petclinic` for URL, `petclinic` for username/password) while also supporting overrides via environment variables (`MYSQL_URL`, `MYSQL_USER`, `MYSQL_PASS`). This approach enhances portability and security by allowing credentials and connection details to be managed externally. Additionally, the file specifies `spring.sql.init.mode=always`, which instructs Spring to execute SQL initialization scripts every time the application starts. This is explicitly noted as safe due to the idempotent nature of the SQL scripts, ensuring that schema creation or data population can be run repeatedly without adverse effects. This setup is crucial for development, testing, and even production environments requiring consistent database schema or initial data loading.

attributes.name: database
attributes.description: Specifies the primary database type to be used, set to MySQL.

attributes.name: spring.datasource.url
attributes.description: The JDBC URL for connecting to the database. Defaults to a local MySQL instance but can be overridden by the MYSQL_URL environment variable.

attributes.name: spring.datasource.username
attributes.description: The username for database authentication. Defaults to 'petclinic' but can be overridden by the MYSQL_USER environment variable.

attributes.name: spring.datasource.password
attributes.description: The password for database authentication. Defaults to 'petclinic' but can be overridden by the MYSQL_PASS environment variable.

attributes.name: spring.sql.init.mode
attributes.description: Defines when SQL initialization scripts should be executed. Set to 'always' indicating scripts run on every application startup, presumed safe due to idempotency.
